div1.p: Pinto lauds Truby for his decision to write an autobiography. He comments on Agramonte's role in the yellow fever experiments.

FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Omaha, Nebr.
August 16, 1941
Colonel Albert E. Truby,
145 Laurel Str.,
San Francisco, Calif.
My dear Mr. (True) as John Chinaman used to call you in Cuba:
div1.p:
I was surprised and glad to hear from you after so long a
period. The last time we met, as you remember, was when you were
returning to Cuba and stopped in Omaha during a change between
trains during Aksarben festivities.

I was glad to hear that you are writing an autobiography,
and am quite sure you will do it justice. I shall be pleased to
look over your manuscript and if I can add anything, which I doubt,
I will also be pleased to do that.

You speak of Agramonte and what he did on the Reed Board.
Of course we know that he was a dud. I have not had any
communication with Dr. Hench of the Mayo Clinic, but I have no
doubt as long as you gave him my name, he will drop me a line.

There are a lot of things that we might thrash over if we
should meet personally, and one thing might bring up another
covered by that historical period. We hardly realized at the time
this was going on that we were making history, but the fact re-
mains that we were writing a definite page for future guidance
particularly in the yellow fever contact and the clearing away
of so much husk and rubbish that we discovered the real kernel.

Hoping to hear from you at your leisure, I am as ever your
friend,
